E952A2C133C14B15B85D453BF018A736.description: (13)  The student recognizes emerging technological advances in science. The student is expected to: (B)  recognize advances in bioengineering and transplant technology.

01669C61B7B9466AA3C3E18B428B324F.description: (A) recognize advances in stem cell research such as cord blood use; and

AFD299ADF21A4A9595001460EC038687.description: (13)  The student recognizes emerging technological advances in science. The student is expected to:

F9A67EE9C78546AF9BDBE71B97E53A51.description: (C)  summarize the human growth and development cycle.

69F7C88A900C440CA587BB2688D65D7A.description: identify the functions of the male and female reproductive systems; and

313E6A8BF9B54F15B67173314828837F.description: explain embryological development of cells, tissues, organs, and systems;

A647DBD1599F41BEA3A766E04CEC1E1E.description: The student describes the process of reproduction and growth and development. The student is expected to:

D3449DCFB09E43F5B1C74D4D0D8B1993.description: examine characteristics of the aging process on body systems.

F1BFD72C17DE4ED9A0B10A4424128721.description: research technological advances and limitations in the treatment of system disorders; and

85757FFBB50742B5BADB1C96AD703DC1.description: evaluate the cause and effect of disease, trauma, and congenital defects on the structure and function of cells, tissues, organs, and systems;

0CF9262F28E94C6DA21EB3F48CE4C176.description: analyze the relationships between the anatomical structures and physiological functions of systems, including the integumentary, nervous, skeletal, muscular, cardiovascular, respiratory, digestive, urinary, immune, endocrine, and reproductive systems;

220D924D392544BB982F8840DD336B64.description: The student investigates the structure and function of the human body. The student is expected to:

347956E3509041339F37E4B24FEB6342.description: explore measures to minimize harmful environmental factors on body systems.

E1BFBA55F67247FBA046F7EA8CDDF011.description: identify the effects of environmental factors such as climate, pollution, radioactivity, chemicals, electromagnetic fields, pathogens, carcinogens, and drugs on body systems; and

DD8F2166367748F780E7B34A15965984.description: The student investigates environmental factors that affect the human body. The student is expected to:

6F0D3A47CBC24C57B4DA2E9E9FFB9DE7.description: contrast the interactions among the transport systems.

94572B04EDAC41E599E2C5285CBC78D3.description: determine the factors that alter the normal functions of transport systems; and

B9EB51B13A364979AFA4A6860F3346D2.description: analyze the physical, chemical, and biological properties of transport systems, including circulatory, respiratory, and excretory;

55E12E84813C43DA813116FAACDA7AB6.description: The student explores the body's transport systems. The student is expected to:

A9DDEA71301E4DCFA513D3691C85887E.description: evaluate the application of advanced technologies such as electroencephalogram, electrocardiogram, bionics, transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation, and cardioversion.

0E460EBFD8BC49D9BEB48F6DA595ABBF.description: investigate the therapeutic uses and effects of external sources of electricity on the body system; and

8948D3ED17144A2090828AFC8168E585.description: illustrate conduction systems such as nerve transmission or muscle stimulation;

6FEE19DE72934AD69CB805327369853B.description: The student examines the electrical conduction processes and interactions. The student is expected to:

EB75187FA5594D178AC8D75FFCE70C94.description: determine the consequences of the failure to maintain homeostasis.

61901AD5F92C443096532D692DDFFFC1.description: investigate and describe the integration of the chemical and physical processes, including equilibrium, temperature, pH balance, chemical reactions, passive transport, active transport, and biofeedback, that contribute to homeostasis; and

6283FF2A28FC4FB38224E5D826135F17.description: The student examines the body processes that maintain homeostasis. The student is expected to:

40DD31512A474D35BFF69983265EF83E.description: perform an investigation to determine causes and effects of force variance and communicate findings.

A833E61EBD024D7D818BD923E5B65A58.description: analyze and describe the effects of pressure, movement, torque, tension, and elasticity on the human body; and

A8B59A7432D047AD909B563788197500.description: interpret normal and abnormal contractility conditions such as in edema, glaucoma, aneurysms, and hemorrhage;

5F70749480C04EE6A56764CF658C05BC.description: investigate and report the uses of various diagnostic and therapeutic technologies;

7E833B647BEB4232BD8C9F1BAA52FC08.description: explain the coordination of muscles, bones, and joints that allows movement of the body;

F3FCCF559AD5425198ADCB696D5508D1.description: The student differentiates the responses of the human body to internal and external forces. The student is expected to:

54F47844D51D40828428AF95674714E1.description: analyze the effects of energy excess in disorders as they relate to body systems such as cardiovascular, endocrine, muscular, skeletal, and pulmonary.

436C12C63F4F49739451C4B815696CB5.description: analyze the effects of energy deficiencies in malabsorption disorders as they relate to body systems such as Crohn's disease and cystic fibrosis; and

29DA23AD8D65465A96D019628694637B.description: evaluate the modes, including the structure and function of the digestive system, by which energy is processed and stored within the body;

F800F956FCA84125BF6F821A2F61CAB1.description: analyze the chemical reactions that provide energy for the body;

4F6ACFD0F14D4088A4C3B1C6BBCF7138.description: The student evaluates the energy needs of the human body and the processes through which these needs are fulfilled. The student is expected to:

1172B317BCD44E09B8A3B6D8ED130FE7.description: research and describe the history of science and contributions of scientists.

A4B2F94D11DD4619B0FD92C9683F42D2.description: evaluate models according to their limitations in representing biological objects or events; and

D1194819321A41F38A9E511FA3965910.description: evaluate the impact of scientific research on society and the environment;

E856942B4ABB4246897C69CBF10070EC.description: draw inferences based on data related to promotional materials for products and services;

D49F42046A8946B4A596FDEB1CAE6F80.description: communicate and apply scientific information extracted from various sources such as accredited scientific journals, institutions of higher learning, current events, news reports, published journal articles, and marketing materials;

9AE19C7436D04CAB8A847E65DA38AD28.description: in all fields of science, analyze, evaluate, and critique scientific explanations by using empirical evidence, logical reasoning, and experimental and observational testing, including examining all sides of scientific evidence of those scientific explanations, so as to encourage critical thinking;

FB233F41235C45528DBE67F201A672F4.description: The student uses critical thinking, scientific reasoning, and problem solving to make informed decisions within and outside the classroom. The student is expected to:

736D4FBC3A374132AFE977CA2852451D.description: communicate valid conclusions supported by the data through methods such as lab reports, labeled drawings, graphic organizers, journals, summaries, oral reports, and technology-based reports.

4D65458B357D4CC3A0F02862A2A9DC2C.description: analyze, evaluate, make inferences, and predict trends from data; and

6A11602E474E4ACEA3C20D949E8C495E.description: collect and organize qualitative and quantitative data and make measurements with accuracy and precision using tools such as calculators, spreadsheet software, data-collecting probes, computers, standard laboratory glassware, microscopes, various prepared slides, stereoscopes, metric rulers, electronic balances, gel electrophoresis apparatuses, micropipettors, hand lenses, Celsius thermometers, hot plates, lab notebooks or journals, timing devices, Petri dishes, lab incubators, dissection equipment, meter sticks, and models, diagrams, or samples of biological specimens or structures;

842E663B7FBF40FFABEB3EE4B742AC46.description: plan and implement descriptive, comparative, and experimental investigations, including asking questions, formulating testable hypotheses, and selecting equipment and technology;

902EA2BB3751445B87062307AAEFCC25.description: distinguish between scientific hypotheses and scientific theories;

9B9D5EE3752B4EDBB91C29E6687A27A7.description: know that scientific theories are based on natural and physical phenomena and are capable of being tested by multiple independent researchers. Unlike hypotheses, scientific theories are well-established and highly-reliable explanations, but they may be subject to change as new areas of science are created and new technologies emerge;

9C6419BB5580404DA7F6F33AA5736FF1.description: know that hypotheses are tentative and testable statements that must be capable of being supported or not supported by observational evidence. Hypotheses of durable explanatory power that have been tested over a wide variety of conditions are incorporated into theories;

EC52A0A7508E495DB48FB8A90FC4B436.description: know the definition of science and understand that it has limitations, as specified in subsection (b)(4) of this section;

1780D5B559374F4BBF6201EB325242B0.description: The student uses scientific methods and equipment during laboratory and field investigations. The student is expected to:

13637F5188AC4177AE3559D2D84BFC79.description: demonstrate an understanding of the use and conservation of resources and the proper disposal or recycling of materials.

D7E4B792A42D48ECB6107AB8172F3683.description: demonstrate safe practices during laboratory and field investigations; and

4EEF9D09E8194DC0B065DEF9404500A7.description: The student, for at least 40% of instructional time, conducts field and laboratory investigations using safe, environmentally appropriate, and ethical practices. These investigations must involve actively obtaining and analyzing data with physical equipment, but may also involve experimentation in a simulated environment as well as field observations that extend beyond the classroom. The student is expected to:

A3043E421BC1454980E2DEDE9353EED3.description: exhibit the ability to cooperate, contribute, and collaborate as a member of a team.

6801E1B9D055497096059DFB78BBD715.description: demonstrate verbal and non-verbal communication in a clear, concise, and effective manner; and

2F017D521DD447BABAF1B8AAEE034200.description: The student demonstrates professional standards/employability skills as required by business and industry. The student is expected to:

AA66AFFC0FA64C11B1BC6C99048185C8.description: Statements that contain the word "including" reference content that must be mastered, while those containing the phrase "such as" are intended as possible illustrative examples.

733D52C4C9EB4486B9D6DA40DAA3F84D.description: Students are encouraged to participate in extended learning experiences such as career and technical student organizations and other leadership or extracurricular organizations.

9940314A0D6646C9874F377FF596D833.description: A system is a collection of cycles, structures, and processes that interact. All systems have basic properties that can be described in space, time, energy, and matter. Change and constancy occur in systems as patterns and can be observed, measured, and modeled. These patterns help to make predictions that can be scientifically tested. Students should analyze a system in terms of its components and how these components relate to each other, to the whole, and to the external environment.

A763A8AFCF614765BE60C397209E3BBB.description: Scientific decision making is a way of answering questions about the natural world. Students should be able to distinguish between scientific decision-making methods (scientific methods) and ethical and social decisions that involve science (the application of scientific information).

1CF00FBD70B3490F9E80E9F162F1DA17.description: Scientific inquiry is the planned and deliberate investigation of the natural world. Scientific methods of investigation are experimental, descriptive, or comparative. The method chosen should be appropriate to the question being asked.

E4697B8A40C04DAE93286C90BEA3CFBD.description: Science, as defined by the National Academy of Sciences, is the "use of evidence to construct testable explanations and predictions of natural phenomena, as well as the knowledge generated through this process." This vast body of changing and increasing knowledge is described by physical, mathematical, and conceptual models. Students should know that some questions are outside the realm of science because they deal with phenomena that are not scientifically testable.

515EC6B04A4E48E5BFCF94680B86CEEA.description: The Anatomy and Physiology course is designed for students to conduct laboratory and field investigations, use scientific methods during investigations, and make informed decisions using critical thinking and scientific problem solving. Students in Anatomy and Physiology will study a variety of topics, including the structure and function of the human body and the interaction of body systems for maintaining homeostasis.

A0AF0A72AFD24FD1BA249D1304F3AF30.description: The Health Science Career Cluster focuses on planning, managing, and providing therapeutic services, diagnostic services, health informatics, support services, and biotechnology research and development.

9F31FE1980DF43B5A0661D59144941E5.description: Career and technical education instruction provides content aligned with challenging academic standards and relevant technical knowledge and skills for students to further their education and succeed in current or emerging professions.

F336570BDACD445E8DBE1F5268093507.description: General requirements. This course is recommended for students in Grades 10-12. Prerequisite: Biology and a second science credit. Recommended prerequisite: a course from the Health Science Career Cluster. Students must meet the 40% laboratory and fieldwork requirement. This course satisfies a high school science graduation requirement. Students shall be awarded one credit for successful completion of this course.
